content.description:
Gear at the bottom, bolts up top, anchor. Starts on easy terrain with plenty of pro and gets harder beginning at the slanted crack under the roof. Exit right to a small ledge and the first bolt. Continue up to the anchors on bolts. Bring an alpine draw for your last piece under the roof, and perhaps a somewhat longer sport draw to minimize rope drag at one bolt

At the right side of Morphine Wall.
Standard rack; a 0.5 cam will protect the roof, along with an alpine (120cm) draw. Sport draws for the upper section, though a single longer one partway up will prevent the rope from running over a small edge.

At the left end of Morphine Ledge Wall is  is chute.  This prominent line of weakness starts through broken terrain and tends in a generally left direction over broken terrain.  The lower section of the route can be a bit spooky; test the holds before using them.  However, half way up, the route gives way to solid terrain.  You will top out at a ledge just below the cliff top.  Belay here.  Rappelling from where you belayed your partner up is problematic, as it is a less than optimal wrap location.  To depart the route are two options: 1) ascend the obvious line of weakness to the cliff top; 2) down climb to the ledge one meter below where you belayed and rappel at the wrap station.

Trad

At Morphine are two prominent roofs.  Bisecting these two roofs is a book fold.  At the base is a yellow '39.'  This is your route.  Ascend the face.  Pull the crux move and continue up to the book fold and step left to the ledge with the large cedar tree.  From here you wrap.  An alternative is to continue up the roof through the crack, which is 5.10.  This is a very well protected route.  It is very much a Seneca style 5.7, so expect technical climbing and committing moves.

Protection: G.

A beautiful and inspiring route. The roof is intimidating but the difficult section is short. Scramble up pitch 1 (5.7) to the Morphine Ledge. Climb a finger crack to the roof with a fixed nut in the corner. A 10' hand crack in the roof gives way to a vertical off-width before a short finish to the anchor



The obvious giant roof with the hand crack

Cams from .4-3", fixed nut in corner of roof at the top of the finger crack. Rings at the anchor
This is an imposing wall with a variety of trad and mixed lines.
